title: I Love You, Now Die viewers torn over Michelle Carter as new details emerge
text:
I Love You, Now Die viewers are torn over Michelle Carter’s part in Conrad Roy’s suicide (Picture: Sky Crime/AP)

I Love You, Now Die is the gripping new true crime series which has thrown somewhat of a curve ball for viewers as new details surrounding Conrad Roy III’s suicide and girlfriend Michelle Carter’s involvement have been brought to light.

Conrad’s body was discovered in 2014 before police discovered disturbing messages on the teenager’s phone from Michelle encouraging her boyfriend to take his own life.

‘Drink bleach’ and ‘Hang yourself jump off a building stab yourself idk theres (Sic.) lots of ways,’ are just two of thousands of texts from Michelle, spurring on one of the blurriest cases in recent memory.

The couple from Massachusetts met only a handful of times over two years, but shared countless destructive conversations which eventually lead to tragedy.

Was Michelle to blame for Conrad’s death? The answer divided US public opinion, but the media unanimously painted the high school student as a monster.

The 23-year-old is currently serving 15 months behind bars for the involuntary manslaughter of her ex-boyfriend, but I Love You, Now Die reveals the untold story of Michelle’s mental health struggles, poorly prescribed medication and Conrad’s manipulative texts. At one point, he lied to Michelle and claimed his own mother had seen he was researching methods to kill himself, but turned a blind eye.

Now viewers have admitted they’re more torn over Michelle’s part in Conrad’s death than they were just days ago.

‘Having just watched both episodes of I Love You, Now Die on @SkyCrimeUK, this case certainly wasn’t as cut and dried as I first thought and press made out,’ wrote one stunned audience member. ‘A story of love and two f**ked up kids. It’s actually very very sad. #ILoveYouNowDie.’

Another agreed: ‘“I love you, now die” has got me sooo conflicted.’

Michelle encouraged Conrad Roy to take his own life (Picture: Sky Crime)

‘The Michele (sic) Carter case is nuts. I was so sure of what I thought about it, but @HBO documentary spills new info that can’t be ignored. The girl needs serious help, but she’s not a killer. And Conrad was a very manipulative person. #iloveyounowdie,’ and ‘I think I’ve changed my mind a bit now #ILoveYouNowDie not so clear cut,’ wrote two more viewers taking a U-turn.

True crime is still evolving since The Case of Adnan Syed completely flipped perceptions of a guilty verdict. Michelle’s case is one of the foggiest for the ‘armchair detective’.

Consultant Forensic Psychologist Kerry Daynes spoke to press including Metro.co.uk at the launch of Sky Crime to explain the vitality of exploring these complex narratives, which have otherwise suffered from one-dimensional reporting.

‘I think that’s’ what our audience wants,’ said Daynes. ‘Gone are the days when true crime was the Pot Noodle of television, something you’d watch at 2am in the morning and it was bad guy doing something terrible to the ideal victim.

‘I think it perpetuates stereotypes which are harmful in the real world. We live in a world where juries are reluctant to convict ordinary-looking men of rape and don’t believe victims when they come forward. Victims of sexual assault don’t want to come forward in fear of not being believed.’
